docs.abstract: “You can’t just come in and say let’s close up the United States of America,” the president said, insisting again that he did not view the coronavirus as any more dangerous than the flu.
docs.snippet: “You can’t just come in and say let’s close up the United States of America,” the president said, insisting again that he did not view the coronavirus as any more dangerous than the flu.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Tuesday that he wanted to reopen the country for business by Easter, on April 12, despite widespread warnings from public health experts that the worst effects of the coronavirus were still weeks away and that lifting the restrictions now in place would result in unnecessary deaths.

headline.main: Trump Wants U.S. ‘Opened Up’ by Easter, Despite Health Officials’ Warnings
headline.print_headline: President Wants the Economy ‘Opened Up’ by Easter

byline.original: By Annie Karni and Donald G. McNeil Jr

docs.abstract: Without continued humanitarian assistance, the U.N. warned, crisis areas will be unable to contain the coronavirus, potentially killing millions of people.
docs.snippet: Without continued humanitarian assistance, the U.N. warned, crisis areas will be unable to contain the coronavirus, potentially killing millions of people.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nations reeling from conflict, poverty and deficient health care will be unable to contain the coronavirus without significant international assistance, risking that the disease will ricochet back to recovering populations in a deadly global cycle, the United Nations warned in a new $2 billion appeal to combat the pandemic.

headline.main: U.N. Issues $2 Billion Appeal to Combat Virus and Urges Aid for Other Crises

docs.abstract: Top Democrats and administration officials said they were optimistic about finalizing a compromise on a $2 trillion economic package after agreeing to add oversight for a bailout fund.
docs.snippet: Top Democrats and administration officials said they were optimistic about finalizing a compromise on a $2 trillion economic package after agreeing to add oversight for a bailout fund.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional leaders and Trump administration officials closed in on a deal on Tuesday on a roughly $2 trillion economic stabilization plan to respond to the coronavirus pandemic, after agreeing to Democratic demands to add oversight requirements for a $500 billion government bailout fund for distressed companies.

headline.main: Democrats Near Deal With White House on Stimulus Package
headline.print_headline: Aid Deal Near as Trump Pushes to Ease Limits

byline.original: By Emily Cochrane and Nicholas Fandos

docs.abstract: Officials are trying to determine the military’s role in safeguarding the United States from a new enemy within its borders, even as commanders fear infection across the ranks.
docs.snippet: Officials are trying to determine the military’s role in safeguarding the United States from a new enemy within its borders, even as commanders fear infection across the ranks.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than 18 years, the United States military has been defined by Washington’s wars overseas, with hundreds of thousands of troops rotating through far-flung hot spots, fighting battles in places many Americans can barely pronounce, let alone point to on a map.

headline.main: Pentagon Takes Restrained Role in Coronavirus Response, Despite Calls for Help

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

byline.original: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt

docs.abstract: The Kentucky Republican’s diagnosis has injected a shot of fear into the Senate as it scrambles to pass a relief package to respond to the pandemic.
docs.snippet: The Kentucky Republican’s diagnosis has injected a shot of fear into the Senate as it scrambles to pass a relief package to respond to the pandemic.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In another workplace, in another town, the news that a colleague who, days and even hours before testing positive for the novel coronavirus, had been dining and meeting and working out alongside his co-workers might have spurred some drastic measures.

headline.main: Rand Paul’s Positive Coronavirus Test Sets the (Still Meeting) Senate on Edge

docs.abstract: Lawmakers are eyeing the appointment of a new inspector general to keep tabs on Treasury’s $500 billion “slush fund.”
docs.snippet: Lawmakers are eyeing the appointment of a new inspector general to keep tabs on Treasury’s $500 billion “slush fund.”
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the most contentious questions dogging talks over the $2 trillion economic stabilization bill revolves around how to ensure that such a sweeping bailout is administered fairly and without preferential treatment.

headline.main: The Oversight Playbook From 2008 Returns as Bailout Swells
headline.print_headline: Dusting Off the Oversight Playbook From 2008

byline.original: By Alan Rappeport and Jeanna Smialek

docs.abstract: An estimate of the number of possible deaths and polling that showed a cautious public changed, for now, the president’s approach to the coronavirus pandemic.
docs.snippet: An estimate of the number of possible deaths and polling that showed a cautious public changed, for now, the president’s approach to the coronavirus pandemic.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The numbers the health officials showed President Trump were overwhelming. With the peak of the coronavirus pandemic still weeks away, he was told, hundreds of thousands of Americans could face death if the country reopened too soon.

headline.main: Behind Trump’s Reversal on Reopening the Country: 2 Sets of Numbers
headline.print_headline: Why President  Let Go of Goal Of Easter Reset

byline.original: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

docs.abstract: “We are not at war,” the captain of the carrier Theodore Roosevelt wrote. “Sailors do not need to die. If we do not act now, we are failing to properly take care of our most trusted asset — our sailors.”
docs.snippet: “We are not at war,” the captain of the carrier Theodore Roosevelt wrote. “Sailors do not need to die. If we do not act now, we are failing to properly take care of our most trusted asset — our sailors.”
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The captain of an American aircraft carrier deployed to the Pacific Ocean has pleaded with the Pentagon for more help as a coronavirus outbreak aboard his ship continues to spread, officials said Tuesday. Military officials say dozens of sailors have been infected.

headline.main: Captain of Aircraft Carrier Pleads for Help as Virus Cases Increase Onboard
headline.print_headline: Cases Spiral Aboard an Aircraft Carrier, and a Commander Pleads for Help

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

byline.original: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Helene Cooper

docs.abstract: Yet there is no indication Nicolás Maduro will step down, despite little assistance to confront the coronavirus and losing an economic lifeline during an oil spat between Russia and Saudi Arabia.
docs.snippet: Yet there is no indication Nicolás Maduro will step down, despite little assistance to confront the coronavirus and losing an economic lifeline during an oil spat between Russia and Saudi Arabia.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is seizing on Venezuela’s economic pain and the coronavirus threat to push a new plan for a power-sharing government in Caracas until presidential elections can be held this year.

headline.main: U.S. Counts on Global Crises to Press Again for Power Shift in Venezuela
headline.print_headline: U.S. Leveraging Crises To Press Venezuelan Plan

docs.abstract: A report by Amnesty International challenges the American military’s claim that the February strikes hit only terrorists and no innocent bystanders.
docs.snippet: A report by Amnesty International challenges the American military’s claim that the February strikes hit only terrorists and no innocent bystanders.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two American airstrikes in Somalia in February killed two civilians and injured three more, the human rights group Amnesty International has alleged in a new report. The United States Africa Command has acknowledged those strikes happened, but said they killed only terrorists with the Qaeda-affiliated group Al Shabab.

headline.main: Human Rights Group Says Two U.S. Strikes Killed Somali Civilians
headline.print_headline: Amnesty International Says U.S. Airstrikes on Al Shabab Killed Somali Civilians

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

byline.original: By Charlie Savage and Helene Cooper
